metadata.case_name: Custodian, Evacuee Property, Punjab & Ors. v. Jafran Begum

facts.text: The house in dispute is situate in Malerkotla and belonged to one Muradbux who died sometime in 1922.
In 1947, the house was in possession of Muradbux's son, Mohd. Rafiq and Muradbux's widow, Jafran Begum.
Sometime after partition, Mohd. Rafiq migrated to Pakistan.
Notice was issued under S. 7 of the Act to Dildar son of Mohd. Rafiq to show cause why the house be declared as evacuee property. No notice was however issued to respondent Jafran Begum.

Dildar appeared before the Deputy Custodian and admitted that his father had migrated to Pakistan. So on June 7, 1952, the house was declared to be evacuee property. No appeal was taken against this order which thus became final.
Muradbux made a will in 1918 bequeathing the house to Jafran Begum.
On March 2, 1954, the respondent filed an application before the Custodian claiming that by virtue of the will she was the owner of the entire property.

On July 3, 1954, the Custodian held that under Mohammedan law a person could not will away more than one-third of his property and as it had not been proved that the house willed away by Muradbux was one-third of his entire property or less, the will could not be acted upon. In consequence the application was dismissed.
Thereafter the respondent made some representations to the then Government of PEPSU but it is not known what happened thereto.

On September 10, 1956, the respondent applied for review of the order of the Custodian dated July 3, 1954. That review application was dismissed on April 5, 1957 mainly on the ground that it was belated.
The respondent then went in revision to the Deputy Custodian General but her revision was dismissed on September 27, 1957.

On December 3, 1958, the Deputy Custodian General suo motu reviewed the order of September 27, 1957 holding that the respondent as the widow was entitled to one-eighth share under Mohammedan law. He therefore held that only seven-eighths share of the house became evacuee property and one-eighth share of the respondent was not evacuee property.

In the meantime, the suit out of which the present appeal has arisen was filed by the respondent on March 3, 1958. She based her case on the will of Muradbux and prayed for a permanent injunction against the Custodian Evacuee Property Punjab and others barring them from evicting her from the house in dispute.
The suit was dismissed on December 31, 1958 by the trial court holding that the civil court had no jurisdiction to decide the matter in the face of S. 46 of the Act.
The respondent then went in appeal to the Additional District Judge who held that civil courts had no jurisdiction and therefore dismissed the appeal.

The respondent then went in second appeal to the Punjab High Court. The learned Single Judge referred it to a larger Bench. The Division Bench noticed conflict and referred to a Bench of three Judges.

The High Court Bench of three Judges held that the question whether certain person was or was not evacuee was determinable by the Custodian, but the determination of the Custodian on a question of title if such question arose was not final and the question of title could be reopened in the civil court.
Appellant obtained special leave from this Court.

legal_issues.text: The only question that arises is the interpretation of S. 46 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, No. 31 of 1950, particularly whether civil courts have jurisdiction to entertain or adjudicate upon any question whether any property or any right to or interest in any property is or is not evacuee property, including questions of title.

petitioner_arguments.text: Civil courts have no jurisdiction to entertain the suit in the face of S. 46 of the Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 46 of Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950

respondent_arguments.text: By virtue of a will made in her favour by Muradbux in 1918 she was the owner of the entire property, raising a complicated question of title which civil courts can decide.

court_reasoning.text: The Act is a complete code in itself for dealing with evacuee property. Under S.7, Custodian decides whether property is evacuee property, including whether person is evacuee and whether property belongs to him, involving all questions of fact or law, simple or complicated, including title.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Custodian acts as quasi-judicial authority; appeals under S.24, revisions under S.27; finality under S.28; S.46 expressly bars civil/revenue courts from adjudicating whether property is evacuee property.

court_reasoning.text: No distinction between questions of fact and law or simple vs complicated; S.46(a) bars jurisdiction broadly; overrides other laws per S.4; does not bar High Court Art.226 jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred in holding civil courts can reopen title questions after Custodian's determination.

court_reasoning.text: Custodian's jurisdiction under S.7 does not depend on collateral fact; whole matter decided by Custodian.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No scope for Mask & Co. principle here.

holdings.text: Jurisdiction of civil or revenue courts is barred under S.46 to entertain or adjudicate upon any question whether a particular property or right to or interest therein is or is not evacuee property, even if involving questions of title decided by Custodian under S.7.

statutes_cited.name: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Complete code for evacuee property; Custodian determines under S.7 if property evacuee (incl. title); finality S.28; bars civil courts S.46; overrides other laws S.4.

statutes_cited.relevance: Person cannot will more than 1/3 property; widow entitled to 1/8 share.

statutes_cited.relevance: High Court jurisdiction not barred by Act.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court allowed the appeal by special leave, holding that civil courts have no jurisdiction under S.46 to entertain the suit challenging whether the property is evacuee property, reversing the Punjab High Court.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside; suit barred for lack of jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act, no civil or revenue court shall have jurisdiction- (a) to entertain or adjudicate upon any question whether any property or any right to or interest in any property is or is not evacuee property...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of S.46(a) central to barring jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: Under s. 7 when deciding whether certain property is evacuee property or not, the Custodian has to decide all questions, whether of fact or law, whether simple or complicated, which arise therein.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on Custodian's full power including title.

key_quotes.text: The Act is a complete code in itself in the matter of dealing with evacuee property.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies exclusive machinery and ouster of civil courts.
